items.title: Generate ohlc chart but get an attribute error?
items.body:
Hi, I am new to cufflinks and want to generate an ohlc chart from yahoo finance data. I got an AttributeError: 'DataFrame' object has no attribute 'ix' in qf.iplot(). 
Any advice is highly appreciated! Thank you!

`import pandas as pd 
import pandas_datareader.data as pdr 
import chart_studio.plotly as py
import plotly.graph_objs as go
from plotly.offline import iplot,init_notebook_mode
import cufflinks as cf 
cf.go_offline(connected=True)
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)

# Get data from yahoo and reanme the columns
df = pdr.DataReader("gs", 'yahoo', datetime(2019, 1, 1), datetime(2019, 12, 28))
df.rename(columns={'High': 'high', 'Low': 'low', 'Open': 'open', 'Close': 'close','Volume': 'volume'}, inplace=True)
df = df[['high','low','open','close','volume']]

# Generate the ohlc chart but with errors -> AttributeError: 'DataFrame' object has no attribute 'ix'
df=cf.datagen.ohlc()
qf=cf.QuantFig(df,title='First Quant Figure',legend='top',name='GS')
qf.add_bollinger_bands()
qf.iplot()`

items.title: plotting from command line
items.body:
Does anyone else have the problem of iplot not working well from the command line?  When I want to plot something from IPython for example, I run something like `df.iplot()`.  This executes, but nothing shows up.  The way around it has been:

```python
# ensure plotly/cufflinks plots to browser
# cufflinks must be imported AFTER this
import plotly.io as pio
pio.renderers.default = "browser"
import cufflinks as cf

df.iplot()
```

items.title: cufflinks support for plotly 4 (offline only package ie. plotly)
items.body:
For background here's [Medium article](https://medium.com/@plotlygraphs/plotly-py-4-0-is-here-offline-only-express-first-displayable-anywhere-fc444e5659ee) on major changes with plotly.

> Starting with this version, the only supported mode of operation in the plotly package is “offline” mode, which requires no internet connection, no account, no authentication tokens, and no payment of any kind. Support for “online” mode has been moved into a separately-installed package called chart-studio.

Although I have seen solutions in issues here with regards to using chart-studio (instead of plotly==4.0), I wanted to make the request for support for the new offline only plotly==4.0 package.

items.title: Can't plot datetime when using 'categories' option in scatter
items.body:
When using 'categories' option with kind='scatter', the axis with datetime values would only show numbers. Below is an example code and the output:

```
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import cufflinks as cf
from plotly.offline import init_notebook_mode
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)
cf.go_offline()
cf.set_config_file(theme='pearl')

df = pd.DataFrame({'x': np.arange(100)*10., 'y':np.sin(np.arange(100)/10), 'z':np.floor(np.arange(100)/10)})
df.x = pd.to_timedelta(df.x, unit='s') + pd.Timestamp.now()
df.z = df.z.astype('category')
df.iplot(x='x', y='y', categories='z')
```
![newplot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16964895/57954752-afc0d580-78a8-11e9-8a1c-3791303b1e24.png)

items.title: AttributeError happened when invoking subplots in plotly >= 3.8.0
items.body:
When I used iplot() to draw subplots in offline like this, following AttributeError happened.
```
import cufflinks as cf
cf.go_offline()

some_pandas_data.iplot(
  subplots=True,
  shape=(len(some_pandas_data.columns), 1),
  shared_xaxes=True
)
```
```
~/envs/liu/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cufflinks/tools.py in get_subplots(rows, cols, shared_xaxes, shared_yaxes, start_cell, theme, base_layout, **kwargs)
    892 
    893         layout= base_layout if base_layout else getLayout(theme,**check_kwargs(kwargs,__LAYOUT_AXIS))
--> 894 	sp=py.plotly.tools.make_subplots(rows=rows,cols=cols,shared_xaxes=shared_xaxes,
    895                                                                                    shared_yaxes=shared_yaxes,print_grid=False,
    896 											start_cell=start_cell,**kwargs)

AttributeError: module 'chart_studio.tools' has no attribute 'make_subplots'
```

Error only happened in case of plotly >= 3.8.0. 

I think it maybe caused by this change, but I'm not sure. 
Could anyone provide any information on this? Thanks!
https://github.com/plotly/plotly.py/commit/3678aa925489b9ed429dc28863040dbb391dadb1

items.title: Heatmap issue
items.body:
Trying to plot a heatmap raises the following error:
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'min'

This is because of the following lines:
zmin=z.min()
zmax=z.max()

where z is a list. Propose converting these lines to:
zmin=min(z)
zmax=max(z)

Can any one look into it? Thanks exple: ``` data = { 'time': ['10:00:00.001001','10:00:00.020020','10:00:00.003030','10:00:00.040015','10:00:00.050025','10:00:00.060036'], 'color': ['red','orange', 'blue', 'orange', 'orange', 'red'], 'duration': ['0.01020642', '0.01332378', '0.01018166', '0.01882410', '0.01899997', '0.01169282']} df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(data) df.time= pd.to_datetime(df.time,format='%H:%M:%S.%f') df.duration = df.duration.astype(float) df.iplot(kind='scatter', mode='markers', x='time', y='duration') ``` if i try to use categories to differentiate different color, it will messed up the xaxis `df.iplot(kind='scatter', mode='markers', x='time', y='duration', categories='color')` (i saw that there is a ticket fr that already now if i use the following: 1. `df.iplot(kind='scatter', mode='markers', x='time', y='duration',colors='color') ` I will get > CufflinksError: Not a valid color: color 2. now if use the column color to get the color i want using `df.iplot(kind='scatter', mode='markers', x='time', y='duration',colors=df.color) ` i get > ValueError: The truth value of a Series is ambiguous. items.title: XAxis switches from dates to numbers with categories
items.body:
When making a scatterplot with a date variable on the x-axis, the axis switches to numbers (I think in milliseconds) when passing in `categories`. 

```
import pandas as pd
import cufflinks
cufflinks.go_offline()

df = pd.read_parquet(
    'https://github.com/WillKoehrsen/Data-Analysis/blob/master/plotly/data/medium_data_2019_01_06?raw=true'
)

df.iplot(kind='scatter', y='claps', x='published_date', mode='markers')

df.iplot(kind='scatter', y='claps', x='published_date', mode='markers',
             categories='publication')
```

First plot with correct dates on xaxis

![screen shot 2019-01-06 at 09 05 07 cst](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17484616/50737729-3b578680-1192-11e9-864d-3d93034f6766.png)

Second plot with categories and numbers on xaxis

![screen shot 2019-01-06 at 09 05 34 cst](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17484616/50737738-47434880-1192-11e9-8a55-c0a67fc1e020.png)

Passing in a `layout` specifying the xaxis as dates: `layout=dict(xaxis=dict(type='date'))` results in an empty plot

![screen shot 2019-01-06 at 09 09 51 cst](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17484616/50737808-dfd9c880-1192-11e9-8dba-732575154b58.png)

Currently, I'm trying to use a formatter for the Xaxis to convert the numbers into dates, but having issues figuring it out.

items.title: hline=0 causes incorrect plot
items.body:
__Versions__: cufflinks 0.14.6,  plotly 3.3.0

__Sample code__:
```python
import cufflinks as cf
import pandas as pd

ds = pd.DataFrame({'x':[0,1],'y':[1,-1]})
ds.iplot(hline=0,x="x",y="y")
```
results in plotting the line diagonally (from lower left to upper right corner of  plot)  instead of horizontally.
For any nonzero value (e.g.: `hline=0.0001` ) the plot is OK.

items.body:
`study={'kind':'volume',
			   'name':name,

						 'str':None},`

Instead of passing 'changecolor':True, this needs to be 'changecolor':colorchange

items.title: Multiple output in Quant Figure
items.body:
In quant_figure.py

```python
    def __repr__(self):
        _d = self.__dict__.copy()
        del _d['df']
        print(json.dumps(_d, sort_keys=True, indent=4))
        return ''
```
maybe it should like

```python
    def __repr__(self):
        _d = self.__dict__.copy()
        del _d['df']
        return (json.dumps(_d, sort_keys=True, indent=4))
```

items.title: 0.14.1 QuantFig OHLC Candlesticks Missing;  X & Y Axis issues
items.body:
First off, thanks guys for a great tool, appreciate your efforts.

The out of the box [Quantfig demo](https://github.com/santosjorge/cufflinks/blob/master/Cufflinks%20Tutorial%20-%20Quantfig.ipynb) does not behave as expected:

1. Plot does not display the price candlesticks; only the bands and mid line appear. Y-Axis has -ve price values.

2. If we remove the call to qf.add_bollinger_bands() the candlesticks display ok but the x axis dates appear as raw float values.  A work around for this is to convert the Dataframe datetime index to string, eg : `df.index = df.index.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')`.  Also Y axis values appear -ve.

My environment:
Cufflinks 0.14.1
Plotly 3.2.0. 
Jupyter on Ubuntu 18.04
Python 3.7.

```
# reproduce missing candlesticks on 0.14.1
import cufflinks as cf
cf.set_config_file(sharing='public',theme='pearl',offline=False)
cf.go_offline()
df=cf.datagen.ohlc()
qf=cf.QuantFig(df,title='First Quant Figure',legend='top',name='GS')
qf.add_bollinger_bands()
qf.iplot()
```
![newplot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17710514/45484326-9d0b6500-b74b-11e8-8330-998279582abf.png)

![newplot 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17710514/45484687-e14b3500-b74c-11e8-86e3-5d9af03d29c8.png)

items.title: 0.14.1 Breaks Python 2 Compatibility
items.body:
When we attempt to upgrade from 0.13 to 0.14.1, we find that the package fails to install. The culprit appears to be https://github.com/santosjorge/cufflinks/commit/b0480acd0ac9576d47c2fb9c2e823e4b8915ec2f, which uses Python 3 style `open`.

This may be fixable by switching to `io.open`, but I'm wary of submitting a pull request, in case the dropping of Python 2 support is deliberate.

items.body: ~The following code should produce a scatter plot~, but it actually generates a line plot ```python cf.datagen.scatter3d(2,5).iplot(kind='scatter3d', x='x', y='y', z='z') ``` This issue is "fixed" by the `categories` option: ```python cf.datagen.scatter3d(2,5).iplot(kind='scatter3d', x='x', y='y', z='z', categories='categories') ``` Same issue for 2D scatter plot `kind='scatter'`.

items.title: The `zrange` option should affect heatmap's colorbar range
items.body: Heatmap uses the max&min of data as the colorbar range: ```python df = pd.DataFrame(data=np.arange(20).reshape(5, 4), columns=['A', 'B', 'C', 'D']) df.iplot(kind='heatmap', colorscale='-rdbu') ``` However, when using diverging colormaps like `rdbu`, the colorbar should typically center at 0 (to show differences). With native Plotly, the code would be: ```python from plotly.offline import iplot import plotly.graph_objs as go trace = go.Heatmap(z=df.values.T, y=df.columns, zmin=-20, zmax=20, colorscale=cf.get_colorscale('-rdbu')) fig = go.Figure(data=[trace], layout=go.Layout(width=600, height=400)) iplot(fig) ``` `df.iplot()` does have a `zrange` option, but it cannot be used for heatmap. (Although it works for scatter3d). The following code leads to an error. ```python df.iplot(kind='heatmap', colorscale='rdbu', zrange=[-20, 20]) ``` ```python --------------------------------------------------------------------------- AttributeError Traceback (most recent call last) in () 1 df = pd.DataFrame(data=np.arange(20).reshape(5, 4), columns=['A', 'B', 'C', 'D']) ----> 2 df.iplot(kind='heatmap', colorscale='rdbu', zrange=[-20, 20]) ~/Research/Computing/miniconda3/envs/geo/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cufflinks/plotlytools.py in _iplot(self, data, layout, filename, sharing, kind, title, xTitle, yTitle, zTitle, theme, colors, colorscale, fill, width, dash, mode, symbol, size, barmode, sortbars, bargap, bargroupgap, bins, histnorm, histfunc, orientation, boxpoints, annotations, keys, bestfit, bestfit_colors, mean, mean_colors, categories, x, y, z, text, gridcolor, zerolinecolor, margin, labels, values, secondary_y, secondary_y_title, subplots, shape, error_x, error_y, error_type, locations, lon, lat, asFrame, asDates, asFigure, asImage, dimensions, asPlot, asUrl, online, **kwargs) 694 bargap=bargap,bargroupgap=bargroupgap,annotations=annotations,gridcolor=gridcolor, 695 dimensions=dimensions, --> 696 zerolinecolor=zerolinecolor,margin=margin,is3d='3d' in kind,**l_kwargs) 697 698 if not data: ~/Research/Computing/miniconda3/envs/geo/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cufflinks/tools.py in getLayout(kind, theme, title, xTitle, yTitle, zTitle, barmode, bargap, bargroupgap, margin, dimensions, width, height, annotations, is3d, **kwargs) 266 layout['scene']['{0}axis'.format(r)].update(range=kwargs['{0}range'.format(r)]) 267 else: --> 268 layout['{0}axis1'.format(r)].update(range=kwargs['{0}range'.format(r)]) 269 270 # Need to update this for an add_axis approach. AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'update' ```

items.title: set_config_file(colorscale='xxx') has no effect on heatmap
items.body: I want to set `rdbu` as the default colormap, but it has no effect: ``` cf.set_config_file(colorscale='rdbu') cf.datagen.heatmap(20,20).iplot(kind='heatmap') ``` Colormap can only be set by directly passing `colorscale` to `iplot`: ``` cf.datagen.heatmap(20,20).iplot(kind='heatmap', colorscale='rdbu') ```

items.title: Change the default figure margin by set_config_file()
items.body: `cf.set_config_file(dimensions=[w,h])` is very convenient for configuring figure sizes (the default size is too large for notebook), but when the size gets small, the margin starts to take a lot of space. Here's a minimum reproducible example: ``` cf.set_config_file(dimensions=[400, 250]) df = cf.datagen.lines(1,1000) df.iplot() ``` This can be fixed by `df.iplot(margin=(l,r,b,t))`, as shown below. ``` cf.set_config_file(dimensions=[400, 250]) df = cf.datagen.lines(1,1000) df.iplot(margin=[50,50,50,50]) ``` But I wonder if it is possible to configure margin globally? I can't find such an option in `set_config_file`.

items.title: Reuse saved in config file colorscale value
items.body:
Hi. There is a property 'colorscale' in set_config_file method. And I think it is expected that it should be used in iplot method, but it's not. I wanted to fix that but don't know how to implement it best

I would expect something like this in plotlytools.py (line 686)
```
if colorscale is None:
    config_colorscale = auth.get_config_file()['colorscale']
    colorscale=config_colorscale if config_colorscale is not None else theme_config['colorscale'] if 'colorscale' in theme_config else 'dflt'
```
but there is a problem, 'colorscale' always exists in config_file. As one of possible solutions I see changing method set_config_file to save colorscale even if it's None. 
So logic is next, if you want to remember your colorscale call method:
```
cufflinks.set_config_file(colorscale='polar')
```
if you want to use default colorscale call method:
```
cufflinks.set_config_file()
```

But such approach has one minus. Users who alredy have used cufflinks have their config file with filled colorscale. And it's property will be used always.
For example, someone has set theme to 'ggplot' but colorscale not. Then he has default colorscale 'dflt' in config file. By current logic colorscale is selected from theme config and is expected to be 'ggplot' but with new logic it will be 'dflt' which I think is not accepted.
Maybe somehow reset that value in config file?

items.title: Configuring plot and iplot
items.body:

For example, for removing one of the buttons in plotly.offling, it's possible to use the following:

In cufflinks, however, there is not such option.

items.title: Elements in a MultiIndex are not always strings
items.body:
Consider the following example:

```
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import cufflinks
cufflinks.go_offline()
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'a': [0, 0, 1, 1],
    'b': [0, 1, 0, 1],
    'c': np.arange(4)
}).set_index(['a', 'b'])
df.iplot()
```
this raises
```TypeError: sequence item 0: expected str instance, int found```
due to [this line](https://github.com/santosjorge/cufflinks/blob/95421b02c5e0b54fea183bee541809bd49a4d1ea/cufflinks/plotlytools.py#L113):
`x=['({0})'.format(','.join(_)) for _ in df.index.values]`

More generally this will happen every time elements of a MultiIndex are not strings.

An easy fix would be convert to string each element before the join, for example with:
```
x = []
for indices in df.index.values:
    x.append(', '.join([str(idx) for idx in indices]))
```
or maybe even better with:
```
x = list(df.index.map(str).values)
```

I can do a PR if you want but maybe you prefer to change it directly (or do not agree with the change).

items.title: Possibility to pass an explicit list of bins to `df.iplot(kind='hist', ...)`
items.body:
See [this question on SE](https://stackoverflow.com/q/45784591/4063051) for major details.

Basically, it seems that the `bins` parameter only accepts an integer, to be interpreted as the total number of bins in the plot. This is a problem when plotting multiple histograms with different data ranges because they get binned indipendently and thus often inconsistently (see above post).

This seems to be confirmed in (what seems to me to be) the [relevant section of the code](https://github.com/santosjorge/cufflinks/blob/ed3e666a017c869ef1c85a05dcdae5e222509b5e/cufflinks/plotlytools.py#L829-L833).

Is there another intended way to explicitly set the bins, like can be done in `matplotlib`/`pandas` directly with the `bins` parameter, or in `plotly` with `xbins`?

items.title: dimensions arg not propogated to .getLayout method
items.body:
Hi @santosjorge,

Thanks for the great library. Since plot.ly has been open sourced, I've been using cufflinks all the time to great fanfare. Kudos.

It seems that the `dimensions` argument in an `.iplot` call isn't passed through to the subsequent `.getLayout` method in generation of a [plotly Layout object with defined height and widths](https://plot.ly/python/setting-graph-size/). This prevents creating a Plotly visualization when working interactively (e.g., offline in Jupyter notebook). Is this by design / intentional?

Minimal working example, demonstrating the resultant `Layout` dict repr not containing `height` or `width`. 

``` python
In [1]:  import cufflinks as cf
In [2]: cf.datagen.lines().iplot(asFigure=True, dimensions=(500, 500)).layout

{ 'legend': {'bgcolor': '#F5F6F9', 'font': {'color': '#4D5663'}},
 'paper_bgcolor': '#F5F6F9',
 'plot_bgcolor': '#F5F6F9',
 'titlefont': {'color': '#4D5663'},
 'xaxis1': {'gridcolor': '#E1E5ED',
  'showgrid': True,
  'tickfont': {'color': '#4D5663'},
  'title': '',
  'titlefont': {'color': '#4D5663'},
  'zerolinecolor': '#E1E5ED'},
 'yaxis1': {'gridcolor': '#E1E5ED',
  'showgrid': True,
  'tickfont': {'color': '#4D5663'},
  'title': '',
  'titlefont': {'color': '#4D5663'},
  'zerolinecolor': '#E1E5ED'}}
```

I have a quick fix for this (if it is indeed an issue), and will submit a PR shortly—thanks! :)

items.title: Can't plot datetime but numbers on x-axis in heatmap
items.body: Please see the question [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34171851/cufflinksplotly-cant-plot-date-time-but-numbers-on-the-x-axis-for-the-heatmap)

items.title: Add support for categories
items.body:
It looks like categories are not supported.

The following fails with an exception:

``` python
from plotly.offline import init_notebook_mode, iplot
import pandas as pd
import cufflinks as cf
cf.go_offline()
init_notebook_mode()

df = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1,2,3,4], 'y': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D']})
df['y'] = df['y'].astype('category')
df.set_index('y').iplot(kind='bar')
df.set_index('y').columns
```

And the following fails silently:

``` python
df = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1,2,3,4], 'y': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D']})
df['y'] = df['y'].astype('category')
df.set_index('y').T.iplot(kind='bar')
df.set_index('y').T.columns
```

Categories in pandas are a great feature and I'd love to see them supported!

items.title: showing multiple small graphs in a notebook cell output
items.body:
For example: assume each row can show 3 figures (maybe we can also adjust the number for very big displays), the output could be:

fig0 fig1 fig2
fig3 fig4 fig5
fig6 ...

when we click a figure, it can expand to 100% in width.

This is very important for dense experiment work, such as CNN (Deep learning). We can plot neuron weights for many neurons (a heatmap for each neuron) easily. And we don't lose global views.

We don't use subplot because it needs to determine the numbers first and we need to hold the handle of a panel. (We don't like too much intrusive code in the framework for assist purpose)

Do you think it can be integrated in cufflinks?

items.title: VSpan argument incompatiable with plotly.graph_objs.Layout
items.body:
Thanks for providing us with an awesome library!

When I try to call

```
import pandas as pd
import cufflinks as cf
import plotly.graph_objs as go

x.iplot(world_readable=False, filename='test/test',
                          vspan = [{
                            'x0': '2015-01-01', 'x1': '2015-12-31',
                            'color': 'teal', 'fill': True, 'opacity': .4}],
                          layout=go.Layout(title='title',
                            xaxis1=dict(title='date',tickfont=dict(size=18)),
                            yaxis1=dict(title='y',range=[0,100],tickfont=dict(size=18))))
```

It seems that the vspan argument is ignored. I have tried to use shapes as an argument with go.Layout, however its actually go.Scatter(layout) that can use the shapes parameter, not go.Layout. Any ideas on how to include both a vspan and a layout object?

Cheers,

Jack

items.title: 'Line' Not Allowed in Histogram
items.body:
I'm following the cufflinks tutorials on plotly word for word and anytime I try to make a histogram, including dataframe scatter matrices, I get the following error:

```
PlotlyDictKeyError: 'line' is not allowed in 'histogram'

Path To Error: ['line']

Valid attributes for 'histogram' at path [] under parents []:

    ['dx', 'orientation', 'stream', 'zsrc', 'ysrc', 'xbins', 'xsrc',
    'visible', 'marker', 'y0', 'tsrc', 'uid', 'showlegend', 'error_x',
    'error_y', 'rsrc', 'xaxis', 'text', 'bardir', 'type', 'opacity',
    'legendgroup', 'nbinsx', 'nbinsy', 'textsrc', 'histfunc', 'hoverinfo',
    'x0', 'ybins', 'autobiny', 'autobinx', 'name', 'yaxis', 'dy',
    'histnorm', 'r', 't', 'y', 'x', 'z']
```

I tried reinstalling cufflinks (successfully), to no avail. Any ideas?

This is the code I'm using:

```
import plotly.plotly as py
import cufflinks as cf
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(1000, 4), columns=['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'])
df.scatter_matrix(filename='cufflinks/scatter-matrix', world_readable=True)
```

and...

```
df = pd.DataFrame({'a': np.random.randn(1000) + 1,
                   'b': np.random.randn(1000),
                   'c': np.random.randn(1000) - 1})
df.iplot(kind='histogram', filename='cufflinks/basic-histogram')
```

(Sorry if this is an inappropriate place to ask this question, if it is, please direct me to somehwere more appropriate and I'll ask it there.)
